clinical_study.brief_title: Co-infections in Children Hospitalised for Bronchiolitis
clinical_study.official_title: Co-infections in Children Hospitalised for Bronchiolitis: Incidence, Clinical Symptoms and Influence of Cohort Isolation

brief_summary.textblock: Observational cohort study in children hospitalized for acute bronchiolitis. Patients are nursed in cohort isolation. Aim is to investigate the incidence and clinical impact of co-infections in this group.

detailed_description.textblock: Observational cohort study in children hospitalized for acute bronchiolitis. Patients are nursed in cohort isolation, meaning that all patients admitted for bronchiolitis are cohorted together, irrespective of viral diagnosis. Aim is to investigate the incidence and clinical impact of co-infections in this group.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective

primary_outcome.description: co-infection acquired during hospitalisation, patient will be followed during hospitalisation and until 1 week after discharge from the hospital, since average duration of hospitalisation in infants with bronchiolitis is 3 days, the time frame will be approximately 2 weeks

secondary_outcome.description: clinical severity defined as, days of oxygen supplementation, tube feeding, dyspnea score, length of hospitalisation

arm_group.description: patients with bronchiolitis are cohorted together irrespective of viral agent diagnosed, thus respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)-positive patient stay in the same room as RSV-negative patients

intervention.description: all patients hospitalised for bronchiolitis are nursed in one room together, separated from patients without bronchiolitis

biospec_descr.textblock: sputum tested for viral agents by PCR-techniques

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- younger than 2 years admitted for bronchiolitis
Exclusion Criteria:
- chronic lung disease congenital heart defect down syndrome
